ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to write a 300 word summary of complex scientific papers, which is a very valuable skill, and how to write a 20-page review paper. I learned a lot of different ways to study social neuroscience.

More depth about neuroscience of social interaction (compared to PSYC 303 Social Neuroscience). A lot of focus on the animal literature which I was not familiar with before. Learned how to more critically read empirical papers and especially how to interpret the figures.

The final paper was a 20 page literature review and I learned a LOT about how to research / write etc from that as well as extensive practice with reading papers during the semester.
I learned how read dense neuroscience papers and the neuroscience techniques that are usually done in the field.
I gained a better understanding about experimental techniques in Neuroscience and how to write a Neuroscience paper.
Neurosci of social inxns, paper writing
You really get to learn how to analyze and understand scientific papers, which is a crucial skill for science majors.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Course was well organized and I appreciate that the whole syllabus (all readings and assignments) were posted early.
The seminar format was fine but not as. much discussion from students as I had hoped. Mostly Prof Chang would describe the papers, students take notes, and occasionally interpret figures or answer questions. I would have appreciated more discussion, maybe in small groups.
I also did not love the animal literature in general, would have appreciated at least one human paper per week to compare with animal models.

I am not sure why the final paper is 20 pages for all students including those who are not writing their thesis for the class. Seems like a final paper could be 10-15 and accomplish similar goals without being long for no real reason.

The paper and subjects are interesting, but class discussion often fell short of what could havebeen interesting. The class operates like a journal club and it seemed most of us were not reading or not willing to talk about the papers. I am unsure of ways to make it more engaging.

Strengths: I enjoyed reading different papers every week and discussing them because this is something I wanted more experience with.
Weaknesses: It was the same routine every week and less opportunities to talk about anything besides the readings.

Strengths: The open, discussion format allows you to easily bring up questions or topics related to the papers for the week.

Weakness: I wish there was more emphasis on neuroscience techniques in general. The focus was primarily on the figures of the paper, and more background would have been good.
Great
I think 2 papers a week is much more reasonable than 3, because ultimately most students ended up reading only one or two of the three every week for the writeup and course participation.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Was a great senior seminar and built nicely on previous Psych credits. Not worth taking as a junior, the most important skills learned were practice reading papers and how to interpret them. Would probably be a good course for Psych BA senior essay.
Yes, but only if you plan on being engaged with the content
Yes! I enjoyed this seminar

I would recommend this class if you're interested in social neuroscience. The class could get boring if you have no interest in social neuroscience, but you also go over some general research techniques in neuroscience that could be useful.
yes! Manageable class for Neuroscience majors
Yes
Yes! I really enjoyed this class! The papers were very interesting to read, and I always looked forward to class discussions.
Yes it was genuinely a helpful course, although it was at times a lot of work.
